pros: Everyone that I work with have been very helpful and supportive. The kids that I see walking around campus are very courteous. They always addresses the staffs and visitors as "ma'am" or "sir". They are also very willing to help and assist. They offer a great benefit package to the employees and reasonable pay, considering that the school is non-profit. Great place to gain experience and for some, to be in a more well paced and laid back environment. Great work -life balance
cons: Non-profit organization means no room for advancement. Pay scale is not competitive with public schools.

pros: The campus is pretty, lots of old trees.
cons: The list goes on and on.

review_title: Very positive experience as a new teacher: middle school level
pros: The administrators and teachers were very nice. The food was great on campus. I made extra money working some of the banquets and special events. The uniform requirement lowered clothing costs. Many of the teachers lived on campus in nice apartments and lovely homes in a great public school district. Wayne is a wonderful town with lots to do. Lots of opportunities to be creative as a teacher; something I see less and less of in the public school these days with all the required testing. Great football and sports events. Benefits.
cons: I like teaching co-ed. The salary was fine for a starting teacher, or if you took advantage of the lower-cost family housing, but I left after 3 years and moved to a public school. The public schools in the area like hiring VFM teachers; they know how to keep order in the classroom. I am not a macho kind of lady and the atmosphere was pretty Male. Still, I found the administrative staff supportive. I only interviewed once with three people: two administrators and one teacher.

pros:
The best part about Valley Forge is its location.
Wayne is a great town with wonderful people, places to eat, and shopping.
This of course has nothing to do with Valley Forge Military Academy and College.
The best benefit of working there is living on campus.
This is a double edged sword however.
If you live on campus you must do community service-- basicly indendured servitude.
The area is VERY expensive to live in, and once you live on campus, you become trapped because no one teaching at Valley Forge can afford to buy or rent in the community on the salaries provided by the institution.
cons:
The most frustrating part of working at the college (and the academy from what I hear) is being managed by an administration that is clueless about educational pedagogy and principles.
The administrators NEVER visit the classrooms and barracks.  They have convinced themeselves that they know their students and they have no idea that the school is largely filled with poorly educated young men (with some women) who have mastered the art of slacking.  
The standards at the school have declined consistently in the past five years, with valued, seasoned teaching staff leaving out of frustration.
There is NO respect for the teachers from the administration, and any attempt to question constantly changing policies can be met with dismissal. 
Since the administration has no clue about the students, they can't begin to address their REAL neads.
It's really a shame because the families of these students pay a lot of money, and the school could really be a great place to live, learn and work.
